conclusion: To determine when Object A and Object B meet, we need to analyze the given velocity-time graph and find the times when their displacements are equal.
The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of an object.
Object A starts with a high initial velocity v0 and decelerates uniformly to zero at t1.
Object B starts with zero velocity and accelerates uniformly to v0 at t1.

premise: Object A starts with a high initial velocity v0 and decelerates uniformly to zero at t1. Object B starts with zero velocity and accelerates uniformly to v0 at t1.
conclusion: At t1, both objects have traveled the same distance (area under the curves is the same), so they meet at t1.
Object A remains stationary from t1 to t2 (velocity is zero).
Object B continues to move with a constant velocity v0 from t1 to t2.

premise: Object A remains stationary from t1 to t2. Object B continues to move with a constant velocity v0.
conclusion: Since Object A is stationary and Object B moves forward, Object B will be ahead of Object A during this interval. They do not meet within this interval.
Object A accelerates uniformly from rest to v0 at t3.
Object B decelerates uniformly from v0 to zero at t3.

premise: Object A accelerates uniformly from rest to v0 at t3. Object B decelerates uniformly from v0 to zero at t3.
conclusion: At t3, both objects again have traveled the same additional distance since t1. Therefore, they meet again at t3.
Object A maintains a constant velocity v0 from t3 to t4.
Object B accelerates uniformly from zero to some velocity by t4.

premise: Object A maintains a constant velocity v0. Object B accelerates uniformly from zero to some velocity by t4.
conclusion: Since Object A maintains a constant velocity and Object B accelerates, Object A will be ahead of Object B during this interval. They do not meet within this interval.

premise: Based on the analysis, the two objects meet at two distinct times: t1 and t3.
conclusion: The two objects meet at t1 and t3.
